An ethyl group usually increases the melting point due to higher molecular weight and increased van der Waals interactions; we estimate this as +10 °C. The ethynyl group adds rigidity to the molecule and can enhance crystalline packing, potentially raising the melting point by +20 °C. The tolyl group adds both van der Waals forces and pi-pi interactions, which might increase the melting point by an additional +15°C. When estimating the combined effects, significant deviations from the actual value may occur, indicating that individual contributions might not be strictly additive, and other molecular interactions or packing effects might play a role. Given the actual melting point is 73.0 °C, the initial prediction appears to be underestimated. Adjusting the influence of the ethynyl linkage to +25 °C and tolyl group to +25 °C would better approximate the actual melting point.
